repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Governance and Opportunity
            Development Policy Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Governance and Opportunity
            Development Policy Loan in Tunisia was rated as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, Bank performance was satisfactory
            and the borrower performance was moderately satisfactory.
            There were eight lessons learned.  (1) Multi-sector
            multi-donor DPLs are an effective instrument to consolidate
            the policy dialogue, which is especially valuable in a
            transition environment. (2) The Bank's bold and
            strategic decision to focus its program in the immediate
            aftermath of the revolution has helped accomplish
            significant results in Tunisia in a very short time. (3)
            That said, the reforms program supported by the GO DPL was
            perhaps overly ambitious, given institutional capacity
            constraints. (4) Single-tranche DPL operations are not well
            suited for ambitious institutional reforms. (5) An efficient
            government coordination mechanism with strong leadership and
            clear responsibility is critical to monitor and sustain the
            implementation of an ambitious reforms program. (6)
            Technical assistance is critical, especially in new policy
            areas where the government does not have
            expertise/experience and where an innovative approach is
            required to change administrative practices. (7) A quality
            M&E framework is needed to effectively assess the
            progress and outcomes of reforms. (8) The location of the
            TTL and most of the team in the field, particularly for a
            complex operation involving other co-financiers based in the
            field, is essential to efficiently and continuously interact
            with the authorities and donors.

docna.cdata!:
Tunisia - Governance and Opportunity
            Development Policy Loan Project

Tunisia - Governance and

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Governance, Opportunity and Jobs
            Development Policy Loan Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
Executive Directors approved the
            Governance, Opportunity and Jobs Development Policy Loan
            (DPL) Project to the Republic of Tunisia in the amount of
            Euro 387 million on the payment terms and conditions set out
            in the President's Memorandum. Executive Directors
            expressed support for the DPL, which would help Tunisia lay
            the policy foundations for a more competitive business
            environment, a strengthened financial sector, more inclusive
            and accountable social services, and more transparent public
            governance. However, Directors stressed the need for faster
            improvements in public sector transparency and
            accountability, regional development, and social sector and
            encouraged the authorities to accelerate progress in
            consolidating the reforms launched in 2011 to secure
            tangible results. Directors also emphasized the importance
            of women's inclusion in the Tunisian economy. Going
            forward, the need to maintain fiscal sustainability was
            highlighted, and in this context, Directors encouraged the
            authorities to improve the targeting of social programs
            toward the most needy. Finally, Directors acknowledged the
            close collaboration between Bank for Reconstruction and
            Development (IBRD) and International Finance Corporation
            (IFC), and other donors in the preparation of the operation.

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisian experience improving efficiency,
            governance, results through public procurement reform

abstracts.cdata!:
This report talks about improving
            efficiency, governance, results through public procurement
            reform in Tunisia. For many years Tunisia has been saddled
            with an inefficient procurement system, in which the
            awarding of contracts often took years, and the potential
            for political interference was ever present. The interim
            government, with the support of technical advice from the
            World Bank,  had passed a public procurement decree. It
            removed major bottlenecks and laid the groundwork for a
            wider public procurement reform program.

docna.cdata!:
L'expérience tunisienne Améliorer
            l'efficacité, la gouvernance et les résultats par la
            réformedes procédures de passation des marchés publics

            réformedes procédures de passation des marchés publics

repnme.cdata!:
Promoting governance reforms and economic
            opportunities in Tunisia

abstracts.cdata!:
Immediately following the revolution in
            Tunisia, the Bank quickly prepared and disbursed an US$500
            million Development Policy Loan (DPL). The DPL provided
            budgetary support which helped the Interim Government
            address the short-term financing needs and meet the demands
            of the January uprising. The reform measures supported by
            the DPL marked a clear break from the past and set the
            foundations of a new Tunisia. A number of reforms have been
            instituted lifting restrictions on access to information,
            allowing for greater citizen participation, and increasing
            transparency and accountability.

docna.cdata!:
Promoting governance reforms and economic
            opportunities in Tunisia

display_title.display_title:
Promoting governance reforms and
            economic opportunities in Tunisia

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Governance and Opportunity
            Development Policy Loan Project : summary of discussion

abstracts.cdata!:
The Executive Directors approved a loan
            in the amount of US$250 million and EUR 168.3 million for
            the Governance and Opportunity Development Policy Loan (DPL)
            to the Republic of Tunisia on the payment terms and
            conditions set out in the President's randomndum.
            Executive Directors expressed strong support for the DPL and
            endorsed its objectives, noting that the governance,
            economic and social sector reforms supported by this loan
            constitute a concrete step by the interim authorities to
            respond to the aspirations of the Tunisian people. Finally,
            Directors highlighted the importance of improving the
            business and financial environment for the private sector to
            facilitate investment and sustainable job creation.

Development Policy Lending

repnme.cdata!:
Tunisia - Governance and Opportunity
            Development Policy Loan Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Governance and
            Opportunity Development Policy Lending (DPL) Program for
            Tunisia is to support the interim government in its task to
            consolidate social and economic change, and prepare the
            ground to complete the transition. This draft program
            document is a DPL to Tunisia in the amount of US$500 million
            equivalent (consisting of an amount of US$250 million and an
            amount of Euro 168.3 million). In January 2011 Tunisia
            experienced an unprecedented and spontaneous wave of
            protests, fueled by persistent lack of social and political
            inclusion, anger over governance and corruption problems,
            and mounting frustration over unemployment and food
            inflation. This DPL supports the interim government in its
            task to bring about the social and economic changes needed
            to firm up the transition. This operation is a key component
            of the World Bank's support to the interim government
            and the transition period in Tunisia. The operation has been
            prepared jointly with the African Development Bank (AFDB),
            the European Union (EU), and the French Development Agency
            (AFD), and in collaboration with the Japanese Development
            Agency (JICA) and United Nations Development Program (UNDP).

Tunisia - Governance and Opportunity
